_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Applicable building, electrical and plumbing codes.  This facility complies with Iowa Fertilizer Law
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: We utilize those provisions of these codes deemed applicable by jurisdictional authorities
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vandalism/Theft (methamphetamine) Provisions have been made to install a protective barrier around the plant perimeter to reduce the potential of vehicular damage
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Breakaway couplers have been installed at the risers and a remote emergency shutoff valve at the storage tank
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: regular plant inspection/routine preventive maintenance and repairs
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: pumps, pump seals, pipes, plumbing, electrical and safety equipment.  Breakaway couplers, relief valves and hoses are also inspected and replaced as needed

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE

This facility complies with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1999 requirements with amendments for Anhydrous Ammonia storage. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal, State, and local regulations. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to immediately notify the Clarinda Fire Department (via a 911 call) and request that it respond to the emergency. Incidental to the notification to the fire department, a call to the Page County, Iowa LEPC will be made.

While we have planned for an emergency, it is acknowledged that a real emergency will be unexpected and may very well be much different and cannot be ensured to duplicate what may have be planned. In reality, the situation that develops may not happen in the manner in which it has been planned. In that event, what may have been planned will serve only as a guideline to follow.

The Emergency Action Plan for this facility describes certain procedures that are intended to minimize the hazards associated with human health and the environment from fires, explosions, the sudden and unexpected release of chemicals (i.e., Anhydrous Ammonia), tornadoes, bomb threats or other accidents or acts of God which might occur on our premises. The primary emergency coordinator for the Clarinda, Iowa location the agronomy  manager.


DESCRIPTION OF THE ANHYDROUS AMMONIA STORAGE/DISTRIBUTION PLANT AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED

This facility is a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution plant. The anhydrous ammonia that is stored at this facility is distributed to agricultural crop producers in the surrounding area who utilize the anhydrous ammonia for crop nutrient purposes. 

The system consists of a storage vessel with associated piping valves, liquid pump, and other miscellaneous equipment.  From time-to-time throughout the year multiple portable nurse tanks may also be present at this site.   The anhydrous ammonia plant is only operated on a season

al basis (Spring and Fall). Full-time equivalent employee numbers were computed on that basis. The FTEs for this company location is five (5).


GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable State and local codes and regulations. The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1999 with amendments and State law. 

In addition the company has specific operating procedures in place intended to minimize the potential for an accidental (and potentially catastrophic) release of anhydrous ammonia. The company has extended to the local fire department the opportunity to visit our anhydrous ammonia plant and to avail themselves of specific anhydrous ammonia health hazard information and training provided by the company.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

The company has not experienced any  accidental release involving anhydrous ammonia in the last five years that caused death, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations or shelterings in place.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

In the event of an emergency involving our anhydrous ammonia system, it is the policy of company to immediately notify the local  fire department and the Page County, Iowa LEPC to request that they respond to the emergency. In the unlikely event that the local fire department is unable to adequately respond to an emergency at our location, the fire department with whom the local fire department has a reciprocal agreement will be summoned.  We have discussed this policy with the fire department and Page County LEPC. Members of the fire department and the LEPC have inspected our anhydrous ammonia plant. In addition, copies of photographs taken of our plant have been provided (for reference) to both entities.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

The plan is to minimize those hazards to human health an

d to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. Employees working at the bulk storage plant make routine observations prior to and during transfer operations of the anhydrous ammonia from the storage vessel(s) to nurse tanks. In so doing, they are able to detect problems before they arise. This routine inspection identifies any portion of the system which may be under stress or about to fail. Repairs can be made before they become problematic. Employees are annually trained to recognize the hazards associated with storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. In addition to annual training for employees who have been on the job for a number of years, the company conducts training for new hires. This training includes classroom instruction, on-site training at the plant, and follow-up observation to determine their individual comprehension and understanding. The company routinely invites local fire department personnel to visit the site. In the event that the local fire department requests assistance in training its employees on anhydrous ammonia, the company cooperates fully in their endeavors.
